captions.text:
A world of ancient beasts, great savage drooling
creatures that normal men and women must find

a way to work around if they ever hope to
live in peace, but enough about the last time

I visited my grandparents, let&#39;s talk about
Monster Hunter World.

Now, I&#39;ve played Monster Hunter games before,
but that was before I experienced my Dark

Souls epiphany and realised I actually quite
like games about banging my head against a

wall for hours on end, because my face hasn&#39;t
been terribly successful in the field of attractiveness

so might as well see if it has any application
in the construction industry.

So I was confident that I&#39;m a little closer
to &#39;getting&#39; Monster Hunter this time around,

which by all accounts is kind of doing its
own thing, gameplay-wise, but can be tentatively

classified as a fantasy exploration crafting
RPG game with difficult boss fights except

instead of the boss fight being at the end
of a level or sequence of linear challenges

they just sort of spontaneously happen while
you&#39;re wandering around looking for herbs

that could fix your erectile dysfunction - action
adventure?
Yeah let&#39;s just go with action adventure.

The plot, such as it is, is thus: in a fantasy
world where everyone dresses like they&#39;re

trying to avoid having to check baggage at
the airport by wearing everything they own,

a fleet of hunters is on their way to a newly
discovered continent full of all kinds of

wonderful new monsters to slaughter so that
they can wear half the corpse and use the
other half to kill all their mates.
But oh no!

Just as we&#39;re making friends on the transport
ship and about to exchange tips on what to

do about incredibly strange tan lines, the
ship runs into what the game persistently

refers to as an elder dragon but which looks
to me more like a giant lump of coal miner&#39;s
snot.

Or possibly Grimace from McDonalds after he
fell into the restaurant grease trap.

The ship gets wrecked and thus begins our
epic quest to seek vengeance upon the elder

dragon before it enacts its dastardly scheme
to continue minding its own fucking business.

Well, I guess we&#39;re not really seeking revenge
since this seems to have been one of those

RPG shipwrecks that kill precisely no one,
the story is instead focussed around researching

monsters and figuring out exactly why elder
dragons are migrating to the new world.

It&#39;ll probably turn out that they&#39;re trying
to get their knob on.

With another elder dragon or, failing that,
an appropriately-sized fatberg.

So one thing you&#39;re just going to have to
accept about Monster Hunster is that you&#39;re

probably not going to be engaged with the
plot, and at first that was feeling like a

deal breaker for me, &#39;cos I consider myself
a narrative gameplay specialist and I just

can&#39;t enjoy banging my head against a wall
unless I know it&#39;s for some purpose I can

relate to on some level, like maybe the wall
killed our family or we have a pressing urgent
need to build an extension.

And while I&#39;ve played quite a few games where
researching and/or cataloguing the enemy is

part of the gameplay, some of my favourite
games even, like X-COM or Castlevania Aria

of Sorrow, it was always in pursuit of the
larger goal, whereas the researching monsters

aspect appears to be the only goal of Monster
Hunter, and the only way we know how to research

monsters is to hack them up with swords as
part of a live, impromptu dissection.

I found it hard to be invested when the monsters
don&#39;t seem to be starting shit with us.

And the plot reason for every hunt and kill
mission is pretty much the same - &quot;Hey, this
big monster&#39;s getting in the way of our &#39;research.&#39;

You&#39;d better give it a damn good &#39;researching&#39;
so we can &#39;research&#39; all its helpless children.&quot;
Be honest with me, are we a bunch of bastards?

&#39;Cos this is starting to feel like the kind
of thing a bunch of bastards might do.

Plot progression is less about the unfolding
series of events and more about adding more
shit to your to do list.

Oh boy we unlocked a new area where there&#39;s
a monster made of ready salted crisps.

Guess I&#39;m gonna have to hunt them like fifteen
times until I&#39;ve got a sword made out of his

dick and armour made out of his bum because
there&#39;s a lot of other monsters with a weakness
for ready salted crisps.

After a while I think the appeal of Monster
Hunter was starting to click for me - it&#39;s

not about the linear story it&#39;s got set up
to put a vague connecting thread through the

world expanding process, it&#39;s about the story
you create for yourself.

The wonderful adventure of Poopants the custom
character and their quest for the mythical
assload of top-tier elemental weapons.

The kind of story that&#39;s almost certainly
going to end anticlimactically when you finally

get that pair of level 20 thunder knacker
clackers and have no more beasts to conquer

and are left only to wonder why you wasted
so much of your recent life hanging around

one giant scaly butt after another chipping
single digit quantities of health off it like

they were little more than a succession of
refrigerators badly in need of defrosting.

Another thing that took a while to click was
the combat, which is where the game happily

throws you in at the deep end by handing you
a box full of 14 different weapons with distinct

attack styles, and when you look up from the
box to ask when the tutorial&#39;s going to start

you realise Monster Hunter has already fucked
off to go lovingly render some juicy steaks

or something and you&#39;ve been left to figure
it out by yourself.

The game does offer a bit of advice, unfortunately,
it is lies.

I started out with the longsword just because
the game gave it three stars for ease of use,

but no shit was clicking the whole time I
was using that fucking thing, unless you count

the clicking of my shoulder joints every time
I raise it up for a basic attack like I&#39;m
trying to raise the fucking flag at Iwo Jima.

Eventually I switched to the dual daggers
because it turns out being able to attack

quickly is pretty important when the monsters
all get understandably jumpy when you have

expressed an intention to make bolas out of
their bo-locks and you need to be able to

stop what you&#39;re doing at the merest hint
of tail whip and roly-poly the fuck out of
dodge.

I think the main thing you need to know about
Monster Hunter is that it just doesn&#39;t do
quick gratification.

You might notice that virtually every optional
hunt mission is &quot;Kill 1 monster and you have

fifty minutes to do it&quot; and that&#39;s not necessarily
a generous time limit.

This isn&#39;t some casual punch the nasty thing
until it stops getting up affair, this is

something you&#39;re gonna be putting some fucking
work into.

Don&#39;t expect explosive action or heartrending
plot, this is a very specific kind of catharsis

that you might be into if you&#39;ve got a thing
for admin.

Getting your head around a fucking database
of crafting menus and stat charts so you can

most efficiently plan precisely how you&#39;re
going to torment a scaly bum for the next
half hour or so.

It&#39;s certainly not for everyone, the lack
of player training, stodgy item switching

controls and the slow process of nickel and
diming agitated scaly bums to death can be

frustrating, and it&#39;s hard to recommend a
game that feels like coming to work at the

lizard buttock data entry department, but
there can be satisfaction in work, and if

you do get into it the world of Monster Hunter
is an oddly charming one.

A surprising amount of effort was put into
making your dinner look really tasty, which

is partly the juicy glisten and sizzle and
partly the sheer flamboyance with which our

character animatedly scarfs it down, and hell,
it never seems to stop being fun to watch.

The last time I got that enthusiastic about
sticking things in my mouth I got done for
lewd conduct.
